forkee.name: big-road
forkee.description: The simplist's solution to the mobile-only web story

issue.title: How to solve the 'UnicodeEncodeError' and the messy code problem?
issue.body:
here are my codes:
```
import requests
from bs4 import BeautifulSoup
import csv

def scrape_onepage(purl):
    r = requests.get(purl).text
    data = BeautifulSoup(r,"html.parser")
    all_div = data.find('div',attrs={'class':"wrapper fixed"}).find_all("li")
    tittles=[]
    for i in all_div:
        tittle=[]
        tittle.append(i.find('div', attrs={'class':"t"}).find('strong').text.strip())
        tittle.append(i.find('div', attrs={'class':"w"}).text.strip())
        tittle.append(i.find('div', attrs={'class':"t"}).find('a')['href'])
        tittles.append(tittle)
    return tittles
def scrape_all_pages(url):
    page_urls=[]
    comments=[]
    for i in range(1,15):  
        if i == 1:
            url = 'http://www.chinabuildingcentre.com/list-41-1.html'
        else:
            url = 'http://www.chinabuildingcentre.com/list-41-{}.html'.format(i)
        page_urls.append(url)
    for purl in page_urls:
        comments.extend(scrape_onepage(purl))
    return(comments)
result = scrape_all_pages('http://www.chinabuildingcentre.com/list-41-1.html')


with open('cbc.csv','a',encoding='utf-8') as f:

    writer = csv.writer(f)
    header = ['titles','comment','url']
    writer.writerow(header)
    writer.writerows(result)
```

It runs ok, however, when you open the file in Excel, it goes wrong.

Before this problem,  I was soloving the unicode problem as follows:
```
with open('cbc.csv','w') as f:
    writer = csv.writer(f)
    header = ['titles','comment','url']
    writer.writerow(header)
    writer.writerows(result)
```

after excuted, it goes:

> ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
> UnicodeEncodeError                        Traceback (most recent call last)
> <ipython-input-142-9921ad8beff1> in <module>()
>     35     header = ['Titles','comment','Url']
>     36     writer.writerow(header)
> ---> 37     writer.writerows(result)
> 
> UnicodeEncodeError: 'gbk' codec can't encode character '\u2022' in position 17: illegal multibyte sequence

I google it and they told me is about the decoding and encoding problem, but I tried to add a parameter'encoding='utf-8''. It still can't be open by jupyternote book which tells me the csv file is not UTF-8 encoded. And when I tried to open it with Excel, it shows messy code again.
So, how can I solve these two problem?

issue.title: How to solve the 'UnicodeEncodeError' and the messy code problem?
issue.body:
here are my codes:
```
import requests
from bs4 import BeautifulSoup
import csv

def scrape_onepage(purl):
    r = requests.get(purl).text
    data = BeautifulSoup(r,"html.parser")
    all_div = data.find('div',attrs={'class':"wrapper fixed"}).find_all("li")
    tittles=[]
    for i in all_div:
        tittle=[]
        tittle.append(i.find('div', attrs={'class':"t"}).find('strong').text.strip())
        tittle.append(i.find('div', attrs={'class':"w"}).text.strip())
        tittle.append(i.find('div', attrs={'class':"t"}).find('a')['href'])
        tittles.append(tittle)
    return tittles
def scrape_all_pages(url):
    page_urls=[]
    comments=[]
    for i in range(1,15):  
        if i == 1:
            url = 'http://www.chinabuildingcentre.com/list-41-1.html'
        else:
            url = 'http://www.chinabuildingcentre.com/list-41-{}.html'.format(i)
        page_urls.append(url)
    for purl in page_urls:
        comments.extend(scrape_onepage(purl))
    return(comments)
result = scrape_all_pages('http://www.chinabuildingcentre.com/list-41-1.html')


with open('cbc.csv','a',encoding='utf-8') as f:

    writer = csv.writer(f)
    header = ['titles','comment','url']
    writer.writerow(header)
    writer.writerows(result)
```

It runs ok, however, when you open the file in Excel, it goes wrong.

Before this problem,  I was soloving the unicode problem as follows:
```
with open('cbc.csv','w') as f:
    writer = csv.writer(f)
    header = ['titles','comment','url']
    writer.writerow(header)
    writer.writerows(result)
```

after excuted, it goes:

> ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
> UnicodeEncodeError                        Traceback (most recent call last)
> <ipython-input-142-9921ad8beff1> in <module>()
>     35     header = ['Titles','comment','Url']
>     36     writer.writerow(header)
> ---> 37     writer.writerows(result)
> 
> UnicodeEncodeError: 'gbk' codec can't encode character '\u2022' in position 17: illegal multibyte sequence

I google it and they told me is about the decoding and encoding problem, but I tried to add a parameter'encoding='utf-8''. It still can't be open by jupyternote book which tells me the csv file is not UTF-8 encoded. And when I tried to open it with Excel, it shows messy code again.
So, how can I solve these two problem?

issue.title: question about array
issue.body:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42830310/45593877-612e0500-b9c2-11e8-932d-b623d862355a.png)
In the image, why is the highlight part '1,2,4' as a result of print? How come the result?
And I'm not quite understand 'Similarly, the first number is to index elements in this array, the second number is to index the sub-elements in each elements', could anyone help me out?

issue.title: Install Python3 on Windows and Set Environment
issue.body:
1. Click [here](https://www.python.org/ftp/python/3.7.0/python-3.7.0.exe) to download Python 3.7.
2. Remember to choose 'Customize installation' and click 'pip' when you are installing python. If you install the default version, you cannot import 'numpy' module in week2. 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42831899/45255308-2111c580-b3b7-11e8-8371-82c3b687956d.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42831899/45255309-253de300-b3b7-11e8-94b8-47f622ece7f9.png)

comment.body: No matter what, every block I saw, I tick it. LOL
